description.narrative: By 2021, Government partners have increased technical and management capacity to provide high impact child and maternal nutrition services, which contributes to Community-Based Management Of Acute Malnutrition, Infant And Young Child Feeding, Micronutrients, Nutrition And Emergencies, Nutrition â€“ General, Prevention Of Stunting And Other Forms Of Malnutrition, Treatment Of Severe Acute Malnutrition, Wash â€“ General. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Evaluations, Research And Data, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: By 2021, disadvantaged children, adolescents, and women utilise quality health, nutrition, water, sanitation and hygiene (WASH) services.

sector.narrative: Capacity building for nutrition preparedness and response
Data, research, evaluation, evidence generation, synthesis, and use for prevention of stunting and other forms of malnutrition
National multisectoral strategies and plans to prevent stunting (excludes intervention-specific strategies)

title.narrative: Eritrea United Nations Development Assistance Framework
UNICEF Programmes in Eritrea (Water Sanitation and Hygiene)
UNICEF Contract Awards through the UN Global Marketplace
2018 Eritrea: Summative Evaluation of the Strategic Partnership Cooperation Framework (SPCF) between the Government of Eritrea and the United Nations 2013-2016 (“Driving towards MDGs”)
Eritrea 2020 Annual Report on Results for Children
UNICEF Tender Notices through the UN Global Marketplace

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: By 2021, Government partners have increased technical and management capacity to provide high impact child and maternal nutrition services

description.narrative: In 2019 UNICEF supported the Ministry of Health to provide therapeutic and supplementary feeding to 58,568 acutely malnourished under-five children, including 16,356 children with severe acute malnutrition (target: 15,000) and 42,212 children with moderate acute malnutrition (target: 40,000). UNICEF and the Government effectively reached 69,390 individuals (40,486 females, including girls under the age of five and pregnant and lactating woman), with blanket supplementary feeding and 362,656 children aged 6–59 months received Vitamin A supplements (target: 300,000) in 2019. | Status:On-track | As-of Date:31/12/2019

title.narrative: Percentage of districts implementing the minimum package to prevent stunting in children
Percentage of health facilities with zero stock out of supplies for the management of SAM as per national standards
Percentage of districts providing care for children with SAM as part of regular health and nutrition services
Number of children aged 6-59 months with SAM who are admitted for treatment
Children aged 6 to 59 months provided with vitamin A supplementation
Children under 5 with MAM admitted for treatment
